notes_fields.Macro:
Four mature examples of Pisolithus sp. were found peeping up in the low grasses at the southeast corner of Pauraque Ridge Farm near Normanna, Texas. The grasses were a mix of native and exotic species. There were also forbs sprinkled around the area, some in bloom (mostly early spring composites and Fringed Puccoon (Lithospermum incisum)). Nearest mature trees at about 10m distance were (Celtis occidentalis). There was one young Live Oak within two meters of one group of Pisolithus. The other groups were not near woody vegetation. Some shrubs, mostly Blackbrush (Vachellia rigidula), were located in a nearby fence line. The topsoil was very dry and hight pH (~7.8). The property had received very little participation over the past several months.

Two representative examples were collected. One was 3.8cm in dia and 5.6cm high (above soil level). The other was 3.5cm in dia and 4.8cm high. In situ and lab bench photographs were made (see attached).
notes_fields.Micro:
Spores were examined at 400x after staining with KOH and images were taken. The spores were globose and armed with short spikes. Spores were reddish-brown in color.

Fifteen individual spores were measured based on a 10µm calibration slide. The measurements did not include the length of the armor. The average diameter was 10.1µm with an SD of 0.55µm.

results.notes:
Growing in the park grass and buried in the needle duff under Picea. Cap with brownish-red warts, margin appendiculate, non-striate. Gills white, staining brownish-red, free, short gills frequent, spores white. Annulus superior and skirtlike, base of stipe very bulbous with chiseling, staining brownish-red. Context white, not changing when sliced, KOH negative. Smells offensive, like musty urine.

See also observation 401734.

notes_fields.Macro: Collected along a grassy trail on a warm dry day with no trees nearby. There were no other species seen and these specimens were not growing clumped together. They were scattered around in the grass several inches apart. Mature examples had tan caps with chocolate-brown gills. Younger examples had pink gills. The area was near a golf course and on the banks of a small lake.
notes_fields.Habitat: The only trees in the area were Black Willows (Salix nigra). There was weeded growths nearby with sprinkled thorn brush.

notes_fields.Macro: This record is an Agaricus species collected at a farm in northern Bee County, Texas called Pauraque Ridge. Specimens were gathered from a grassy area adjacent to a small pond. They were in a path that had been compacted by the tires of a utility vehicle that had been driven around the pond. The only trees nearby were Vachellia farnesiana. Examples were few (five) and scattered over an area of 3m along the trail. Soil was very limy with a pH of near 7.8. More mature caps were convex with the diameter of the largest cap being 3.5cm. Cap texture mostly smooth but there were tiny hairs near the margins. Largest example’s stipe measured 4.0cm long and 7mm in diameter tapering at the base. The stipe maintained the same general color as the cap. Suggestion of a partial veil was present. Gills were free. Younger examples had pink gills that turned dark brown in older examples. No latex was observed. When stipe was cut, the insides bruised from white to orange to brown. There was a faint odor not unlike store-bought Agaricus bisporus. Neither KOH or NH4OH showed color change. FeSO4 treatment stained orange-brown after drying. Spore print was chocolate-brown.
notes_fields.Micro: A single spore (stained in KOH) was measured at 400x to be 10µm x 6.7 µm.

notes_fields.Macro: Collected example of gilled mushrooms on the Coastal Bend College campus at Beeville, Texas. The location was a pond along the hiking trail behind the main campus. Beeville is experiencing drought conditions and the pond is and has been dry, for months. A group of eight basidiocarps was scattered underneath the branches of a Black Willow tree (Salix nigra) but located in dense turf on the sloping bank on the dry pond and these were collected. They all appeared to be mature and most of the spores were gone. Cap shape was convex and of tan to brown color. Cap margins were smooth. Cap diameters were between 2cm to 3cm without tackiness and there was no evidence of latex. Stipes were approximately 3cm long and 5mm in diameter. The gill attachment was strongly decurrent. On the initial posting of these specimens on Mushroom Observer, one member suggested that the genus was Inocybe.
notes_fields.Micro: I was unable to retrieve a representative number of spores from the samples. There were so few that I fear the one I did examine under the microscope could have been associated with some other fungus. If the spores were from my specimens and not some contamination, one of them (see photo) was oval without armor and measured 5µm x 4.2µm (smaller than would be expected for Inocybe)

notes_fields.Macro: Five specimens from a patch of mushrooms found beside the road near the Fannin Battleground in Goliad County, Texas. They were low growing in mown grass and scattered in an area of about 400 square feet. There were no nearby trees. The mature caps were more or less flat, disk-shaped and small. Cap-disk measurements in cm for widest and narrowest dimension were 3.4×2.5, 2.9×2.8, 3.0×2.8, 4.0×3.6, and 4.6×3.8. Cap tops were of a burnt-sugar brown color (RGB 105, 87, 87) and the cap surface was a bit scaly. Gills and stipe were brown. Cap margins appeared eroded so that the gills seemed to hang down from the edge (see attached photos). Stipe lengths were from 2 to 3cm and the diameters were from 5 to 7mm and tapering toward the apex. No color change was observed from bruising. Evidence of a ring was found on two specimens. There was no evidence of latex. The odor was similar to Agaricus bisporus. No color change was observed after the application of KOH, NH4OH, and FeSo4.
notes_fields.Micro: One spore was measured to be 8.7µm x 6.2 µm.

notes_fields.Geology:
Quaternary, Middle Pleistocene: Unconsolidated fine-detrital clay, Unconsolidated fine-detrital silt, and Unconsolidated Coarse-detrital Sand.
Sand, silt, clay, and minor amount of gravel. Iron oxide and iron-manganese nodules common in zone of weathering; locally calcareous. Surface fairly flat and featureless except for many shallow depressions and pimple mounds. Moore and Wermund (1993a) mapped three units—(1) alluvium undifferentiated as to texture and origin—includes meander belt, levee, crevasse splay, and distributary sand, and flood-basin mud deposits, about 60 m thick, (2) fine-grained channel facies (alluvial sand, silt, and clay) about 10-25 m thick, thicker seward, and (3) fine-grained overbank facies (alluvial silt and clay) about 55-65 m thick, thicker seaward. Together, these deposits form a deltaic plain that parallels the Gulf Coast. Unit contains Pleistocene vertebrate fauna, dips seaward beneath the Beaumont Fm. and disconformably overlies deposits of the Pliocene and early Pleistocene Willis Formation. The deltaic plain is entrenched as much as 7 m by streams. In Hidalgo County (southernmost part of Texas) the unit underlies a semiarid plain, widely irrigated and cultivated. Unit is locally veneered with thin, discontinuous stabilized eolian sand.

notes_fields.Macro: A single Pisolithus species was collected from a farm near the Beeville Municipal Airport. Collection site was on a shallow slope a few meters from a small creek. The tree species near the collection site were huisache (Vachellia farnesiana) and Live Oak (Quercus virginiana). The fruiting body was large and potato-shaped (8.9cm x 7.2 × 6.2cm). The outer skin was beginning to crack. Color was light brown-red and spore mass exposed after cutting was chocolate brown. Slight mushroom odor, not unpleasant. No color change from cutting or bruising was observed.
notes_fields.Micro:
Micro:
Spores are globose and densely armed with spikes. Mature fresh spores (not dried) were stained with KOH and photographed at 1000X. The mean spore diameter (excluding armor) was 8.8µm with SD = 1.1µm (N = 12)

results.notes:
Growing among moss and hardwood leaf litter in a hardwood swamp forest at the edge of a Sphagnum bog. One fruiting body attached to a small twig. Unclear if it was the substrate or just adjacent. Not exuding a milk or latex. Lamellar trama inamyloid. Lactifers present in the pileipellis and in the lamellar trama and stipe trama. Smooth, hyaline pileocystidia and caulocystidia present. Spores smooth, hyaline, amyloid and thin-walled. Spore measurements: (6.1) 6.4 – 8.2 (8.6) × (3.9) 4.3 – 5 (5.4) µm, Q = (1.3) 1.4 – 1.8 (1.9); N = 30, Me = 7.2 × 4.6 µm; Qe = 1.6

Mirrored on iNaturalist at https://www.inaturalist.org/observations/39594033

results.notes:
Collected during the Ohio Mushroom Society’s 2016 fall foray. 2 fruiting bodies growing scattered on bare soil in a hardwood forest near Acer saccharum and Fagus grandifolia. Caps hygrophanous. Lactifers present in all tissues. Irregularly-shaped, hyaline cystidia present on the pileus and on the stipe. Lamellar trama inamyloid. Cylindrical pleurocystidia and cheilocystidia scattered. Spores amyloid, smooth, hyaline and thin-walled. Spore measurements: (5.9) 6 – 7.6 (8.1) × (3.7) 3.8 – 4.9 (5.3) µm, Q = (1.3) 1.4 – 1.7 (1.8); N = 30, Me = 6.7 × 4.3 µm; Qe = 1.6

Mirrored on iNaturalist at https://www.inaturalist.org/observations/39594067

results.notes:
Growing from landscaped, shrub sized Coccoloba near highway. Growing within feet of another “Inocybe” species, I. xerophytica. Both are very similar, but the spore morphology easily separates them. In addition, I. xerophytica is smaller, has a “volva” at the base of the stipe (often looks like a ball of dirt), has minute scales on the pileus rather than radially fibrillose “cracks” or lines which run unbroken from the disk to the margin, and the stipe is drab pinkish, or less pale than P. littoralis

—

Mirrored on iNaturalist as observation 150236753 on March 4, 2023.

Medicine Hat, Alberta, Canada

results.notes:
Soft, white, powdery-looking fungal mass growing on the anterior half of a moth pupa in the family Sphingidae (Sphynx moths). Fungal filaments directionally extending from the mass reached upward through shallow soil, possibly toward light (phototropism) or away from gravity (negative gravitropism).

I’d collected the last instar, pre-pupal larva (caterpillar) in late Fall 2019 and placed it into a a mason jar with soil to allow photography of subsequent pupal and adult stages. Like other Sphingids, this moth species burrows to pupate after larval feeding on native and domestic grape leaves.
